speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.4: Student Code of Conduct - The board will review proposed updates to the district’s Student Code of Conduct, which outlines behavioral expectations and disciplinary procedures. Key changes include new rules around cell phone usage during instructional time, updates to the dress code to reflect inclusivity and professionalism, and revisions to disciplinary consequences to promote restorative practices.. Who would like to start?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Thanks, Graham. Ellen, could you walk us through the updated cell phone policy? I'm wondering how we'll enforce it without making it seem punitive. Maybe we could pilot it in one or two schools first?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Thank you, David. I agree with you. I think there's been some pushback already from parents who feel they're being asked to police their children's phones at home. I wonder what kind of evidence we have that having no phones actually improves learning.

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Kate. I appreciate those points.  
I’m curious—how do we know this won’t just shift stress onto families, especially those already stretched thin?  
Maybe we could test it in a few schools before rolling it out district-wide.  
What data do we have showing that banning phones increases engagement or academic performance?  
Could we get feedback from students too, since they’re the ones most affected?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Thanks, Dave. I think starting with a pilot makes sense.  
Do any of the principals think they’d be willing to try it in one building next semester?  
We’ve seen some promising results in other districts—maybe we could look at that data.  
Would it help to give parents a clear explanation of why we’re doing this?  
Kate, did you say you wanted to talk more about the parent pushback?  
Judyl, yes—I think getting student feedback is key.  
Should we survey students at different grade levels before finalizing it?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Good morning, everybody. Thank you all for the comments. And I want to thank Ms. Osborne and her team for putting together these proposals. I thought it was great. I think there's a lot of good stuff in here. I guess my question is where does this fit into our priorities right now? Is this something that we're going to take up again later in the year when things settle down a little bit? Or is this something we're ready to move forward with? Because I've got a couple of thoughts that I've had. One has to do with discipline. But maybe I'll save that until after the break.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Thanks so much, Mr. Alcaro. I don't think I'd be able to answer that question specifically. So I guess I can speak generally and say that I am excited to see some movement toward addressing the issue of cell phone use in schools because I do believe that it's disruptive. I do believe that it takes away from instruction, particularly for younger students. That said, I would love to hear back from someone about whether or not there's data that shows that restricting phone use leads to better outcomes for students. It seems logical, but I'd love to know if anyone else has done research on that.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Katrin, I appreciate your point. I think we might need to gather some data before moving forward. Maybe we could ask Dr. Lujan to look into studies from other districts? Do you think that's feasible?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I definitely think that's feasible. I mean, I would hope that he knows somebody who could help him find that information.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Thank you, David. I do think that we should look at the data. I wonder, though, whether the real problem isn't necessarily cell phones themselves, but rather social media, which is accessible via cell phones. I think it's important that we consider how best to handle that.

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Kate. I appreciate that insight.
I wonder—do we have any idea how many kids actually use phones for social media during class?
Maybe we could check in with teachers and see what they’re observing.
If it’s mostly social media, perhaps we should focus on content access instead of device bans.
Can we get some data on that, please?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Thanks, Jonno. I think we could revisit this after summer.
Does anyone think it’s urgent enough to act now?
Kate, I agree—social media might be the bigger concern.
Jennifer, do you know if we’ve tracked how often phones come up during lessons?
And Judyl, I second your question—are teachers seeing a pattern with social media?
Let’s pull in some teacher feedback before deciding.
Dr. Lujan, could you help us find examples from other districts where this worked well?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Okay, sounds good. I really appreciate that. I guess my last comment is just I understand that it's hard to track exactly how many times students bring their phones to school. But I think that tracking it over a period of time, even informally, might be helpful. And then once we have a baseline, then we can determine whether or not it needs to be addressed.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Yes, I completely agree. I think collecting data is extremely important. I'm hoping that we will collect data around student behavior and make sure that we're not just creating another thing that's unfair for certain populations of students.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Katrin, I agree. We must avoid unintended consequences. Let’s assign Dr. Lujan to collect behavioral data across grades. Please confirm by Friday.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Sounds good.

speaker: kateacuff
content: I wonder whether it wouldn't be better to work with the students directly on this. They're certainly very tech-savvy. I think it would be worth considering asking them how they feel about using their devices during instructional time.

speaker: judyle
content:
Kate, I appreciate that suggestion.  
Have we considered doing a student survey on this?  
I think involving them directly could help shape fairer rules.  
Please, let’s assign someone to draft that survey.  
How soon can we expect it?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Judyl, I think it would be helpful to get input from students. Perhaps we could start with an informal discussion among staff and then expand. I wonder whether we should go ahead and put a version of the revised dress code out for review.

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Judyl, yes—let’s do a quick student survey next week.
Could you coordinate with counselors to reach out to homerooms?
Katrin, I’d like to keep equity top of mind—let’s make sure no group feels left out.
David, please check in with Dr. Lujan on the behavioral data timeline.
Kate, I agree—we should involve students early.
Do you think middle schoolers would respond well to a poll?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Well, I think that's a great idea. And I think it makes sense to try it first in middle school. I'm not quite sure that high school students would be too interested in responding to a survey. But I think it makes perfect sense to do it with middle schoolers.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Yeah, I think that's a great idea. I mean, I was thinking about this earlier when we were talking about how difficult it is to measure these things. I think having a student opinion survey might give us a lot more clarity than trying to count how many times students brought their phones to school.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Katrin, I agree. Let's proceed with the middle school survey. Please confirm with Dr. Lujan by Monday.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Sounds good.

speaker: kateacuff
content: I wonder whether we should include students' views on dress codes as well.

speaker: judyle
content:
Kate, I agree—students’ voices matter here too.
Wouldn’t it be helpful to test both surveys together?
I think we could learn a lot from combining those inputs.
Please, assign someone to draft that dress code survey.
When can we expect it?

speaker: grahampaige
content: Thank you everyone for voting. After counting all the votes, we have 4 (public) / 4 (private) in favor, 0 (public) / 0 (private) against, and 3 (public) / 3 (private) abstaining. Results → Public: approved, Private: approved, Combined: approved. Thank you everyone for coming, have a nice night.
